climbs.name: Wide Body
climbs.fa: Brad Singer and Rob Stauder, September 2001

content.description: Struggle up the tight chimney (facing left seems easier) to a ledge with shared anchors.
content.location:
This is the wide crack just left of

Dragonlance

.

climbs.name: Walk Up
climbs.fa: Johnson Cardmon (solo), Bolts: Chris Miller & Pete Paredes, July 2004

content.description:
A fun romp up a low-angled, featured face and also the recommended approach for the upper tier routes; the anchors provide a convenient way back to the ground after climbing the upper tier routes.

Bolts were added not knowing the route had previously been soloed.
content.location:
The low-angled face/corner just past

Fierce

.

climbs.name: Squeal Like a Pig
climbs.fa: Pat Brennan and Brad Singer, August 2001

content.description: Climb a hand crack which pinches down to a finger crack onto a ledge and then move up and right on easy face to shared anchors on a ledge.
content.location:
Just left of

Wide Body

, an obvious wide crack.

content.description:
This outstanding route tackles an attractive overhanging face via a circuitous route to anchors. Technical and engaging movement on high-quality rock make this a local favorite.

The name stems from weird noises heard on a cold, windy day when installing the bolts with nobody else around; it's also the name of a rock group from the state of Washington.
content.location:
Located on the tallest unbroken face in the area, directly above

Fierce

and just slightly left of

Walk Up

.

climbs.name: Lichen Nightmare
climbs.fa: Chris Miller and Pete Paredes, July 2004

content.description: Climb thin face past two bolts (crux) to reach a striking splitter crack system. Despite the name the route is quite good and the only nightmare was cleaning off all of the lichen on the first ascent.
content.location:
This is the right of two routes that start from a huge ledge with a pine tree above the finish of

Hammer and Anvil

. Either climb that route and top out or access via

Walk Up

about 50 feet to the left (recommended).

content.description:
This route is located 15' right of

Dragonlance

and actually starts on a narrow north-facing wall next to a small pine tree.

Clip a pointless bolt, boulder out the crux, and then clip a second bolt (looking at a grounder) before mantling onto a ledge. Clip another bolt from the ledge and then pull interesting moves (looking at a ledge fall - watch those ankles) onto a vertical headwall past one more bolt and anchors on a ledge.

This is actually a fun route, but the poor bolting detracts from the overall experience; despite that it's still worth a go - just don't fall at the wrong spot!

Long reaches between thin and crimpy edges to a difficult dyno at the top characterize this route which is somewhat contrived as you avoid an obvious flake (the largest hold on the face) at the top.

This route was an abandoned project that finally got some attention, and after a little work it's now one of the more difficult routes at The Coven. Interestingly enough the FA party originally rated this route 5.13b, but it was soon repeated and promptly downgraded to 5.12a! The guidebook split the difference by rating it 5.12c, but what it really needs is more ascents to solidify the rating.
content.location:
Right of

Gorilla Dance

and seperated from it by

Dancing on A Broomstick

(5.7 chimney) is this short, smooth face with a single difficult route.

climbs.name: El Guapo
climbs.fa: Chris Miller and Pete Paredes, August 2004

content.description: Interesting face moves with a low crux to an easier finish on somewhat grainy rock.
content.location:
This is the left of two routes that start from a huge ledge with a pine tree above the finish of

Hammer and Anvil

. Either climb that route and top out or access via

Walk Up

about 50 feet to the left (recommended).

content.description:
This is the 1st bolted route from the left and starts in an obvious wide crack (5.8) on the left.

Start up the crack and the break right onto the face making some tricky moves (crux) just before reaching the 2nd bolt (a fall from here will likely result in a grounder, so have an attentive belayer). Once past that bit of excitement continue up featured face to a ledge with anchors.

The climbing on this is decent but unfortunately the route is marred by the poor bolting at the crux which makes this a poor choice for leaders breaking into the grade.
